Path Homotopy Invariants and their Application to Optimal Trajectory Planning

Subhrajit Bhattacharya
Department of Mechanical Engineering
and Mechanics, Lehigh University, PA.
E-mail: sub216@lehigh.edu    Robert Ghrist
Department of Mathematics,
University of Pennsylvania, PA.
E-mail: ghrist@math.upenn.edu
Abstract

We consider the problem of optimal path planning in different homotopy classes in a given environment. Though important in robotics applications, path-planning with reasoning about homotopy classes of trajectories has typically focused on subsets of the Euclidean plane in the robotics literature. The problem of finding optimal trajectories in different homotopy classes in more general configuration spaces (or even characterizing the homotopy classes of such trajectories) can be difficult. In this paper we propose automated solutions to this problem in several general classes of configuration spaces by constructing presentations of fundamental groups and giving algorithms for solving the word problem in such groups. We present explicit results that apply to knot and link complements in 3-space, discuss how to extend to cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces of arbitrary dimension, and also present results in the coordination space of robots navigating on an Euclidean plane. 111Parts of this paper has appeared in the proceedings of the IMA Conference on Mathematics of Robotics (IMAMR), 2015.

1 Introduction

In the context of robot motion planning, one often encounters problems requiring optimal trajectories (paths) in different homotopy classes. For example, consideration of homotopy classes is vital in planning trajectories for robot teams separating/caging and transporting objects using a flexible cable (Bhattacharya et al., 2015), or in planning optimal trajectories for robots that are tethered to a base using a fixed-length flexible cable (Kim et al., 2014), or in human-robot collaborative exploration problems in context of search-and-rescue missions (Govindarajan et al., 2014). This paper addresses the problem of optimal path planning with homotopy class as the optimization constraint.

There is, certainly, a large literature on minimal path-planning in computational geometry (for a brief sampling and overview, see (Mitchell and Sharir, 2004)). The topology of a configuration space plays a key role in solving path-planning problems. To that end, the study of the topological invariants of robot configuration spaces and the properties of motion planning problems in such configuration spaces is not new (Farber, 2001; Costa and Farber, 2010; Farber et al., 2006; Cohen and Pruidze, 2007). However, most of this body of research has primarily focused on deduction of topological invariants of configuration/coordination spaces, addressed existence questions, have studied properties of the motion planning problem itself, but do not explicitly implement algorithms for finding optimal paths in configuration spaces of robots. Classification of paths based on homotopy has also been studied in the robotics literature in two-dimensional planar workspaces using geometric methods (Grigoriev and Slissenko, 1998; Hershberger and Snoeyink, 1991), probabilistic road-map construction (Schmitzberger et al., 2002) techniques and triangulation-based path planning (Demyen and Buro, 2006). While in a planar configuration space such methods can be used for determining whether or not two trajectories belong to the same homotopy class, efficient planning for least cost trajectories with homotopy class constraints is difficult using such representations even in 222-dimensions. To that end in prior work we developed a graph search-based method for computing shortest paths in different homology classes in 222, 333 and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces with obstacles (Bhattacharya et al., 2012, 2013), and in different homotopy classes in planar configuration spaces with obstacles (Bhattacharya et al., 2015).

Of course, since the problem of computing shortest paths (even for a 3-d simply-connected polygonal domain) is NP-hard (Canny and Reif, 1987), we must restrict attention to subclasses of spaces, even when using homotopy path constraints. In particular, we construct a discrete graph representation of a configuration space and thus reduce the problem to shortest path computation on the graph. This representation, along with path homotopy invariants of the configuration space, allows us to compute shortest paths in different homotopy classes using graph search-based path planning algorithms.

This paper focuses on computation of optimal paths in different homotopy classes in two interesting and completely different types of configuration spaces: (1) knot and link complements in 3-d; and (2) cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006). Compared to our prior conference publication (Bhattacharya and Ghrist, 2015), in this paper we have (i) provided a rigorous Proposition on the presentation of the fundamental group of knot/link complements in 333-d and hence the justification behind the proposed homotopy invariants in such spaces, (ii) have provided an explicit presentation of the fundamental group of cylindrically deleted coordination space for robots navigating on a plane, and (iii) hence have demonstrated through simulation the problem of optimal path computation in different homotopy classes for three robots navigating on a simple planar domain.

2 Configuration Spaces with Free Fundamental Groups

2.1 Preliminaries

In this section we introduce a few fundamental definitions and concepts. Each definition is accompanied by a reference to a standard text on the subject, where the reader can find more details on these topics.

Homotopy Classes of Paths: Consider oriented/directed curves in a topological space, X𝑋X. Two curves γ1,γ2:[0,1]→X:subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2→01𝑋\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}:[0,1]\rightarrow X connecting the same start and end points, qs,qe∈Xsubscript𝑞𝑠subscript𝑞𝑒𝑋q_{s},q_{e}\in X, are called homotopic (or belonging to the same homotopy class) if one can be continuously deformed into the other without intersecting any obstacle (i.e.. there exists a continuous map η:[0,1]×[0,1]→X:𝜂→0101𝑋\eta:[0,1]\times[0,1]\rightarrow X such that η​(α,0)=γ1​(α),η​(α,1)=γ2​(α)​∀α∈[0,1]formulae-sequence𝜂𝛼0subscript𝛾1𝛼𝜂𝛼1subscript𝛾2𝛼for-all𝛼01\eta(\alpha,0)=\gamma_{1}(\alpha),~{}~{}\eta(\alpha,1)=\gamma_{2}(\alpha)~{}\forall\alpha\!\in\![0,1], and η​(0,β)=qs,η​(1,β)=qe​∀β∈[0,1]formulae-sequence𝜂0𝛽subscript𝑞𝑠𝜂1𝛽subscript𝑞𝑒for-all𝛽01\eta(0,\beta)=q_{s},\eta(1,\beta)=q_{e}~{}\forall\beta\!\in\![0,1] (Hatcher, 2001)). A set of all homotopically equivalent paths (i.e., homotopic paths) constitute a homotopy class. We denote the homotopy class of a path γ𝛾\gamma a [γ]delimited-[]𝛾[\gamma].

Fundamental Group: The fundamental group or the first homotopy group of a topological space, X𝑋X, is the set of all homotopy classes of oriented closed loops (paths with qs=qe=:q0q_{s}=q_{e}=:q_{0}) in X𝑋X with a group structure imposed on the set as follows: i. The identity element is the class of all loops that can be contracted/homotoped to the point q0subscript𝑞0q_{0}; ii. The inverse of a homotopy class, [γ]delimited-[]𝛾[\gamma], is the homotopy class of loops constituting of the same loops as in [γ]delimited-[]𝛾[\gamma], but with reversed orientation, and is denoted as [−γ]delimited-[]𝛾[-\gamma] or [γ]−1superscriptdelimited-[]𝛾1[\gamma]^{-1}; iii. The composition (group operation) of two classes [γ1]delimited-[]subscript𝛾1[\gamma_{1}] and [γ2]delimited-[]subscript𝛾2[\gamma_{2}] is the class of loops that are obtained by concatenating a curve in [γ1]delimited-[]subscript𝛾1[\gamma_{1}] with a curve in [γ2]delimited-[]subscript𝛾2[\gamma_{2}] (i.e., it is the class of the loop γ​(t)={γ1​(2​t),0≤t<12γ2​(2​t−1),12≤t≤1𝛾𝑡casessubscript𝛾12𝑡0𝑡12subscript𝛾22𝑡112𝑡1\gamma(t)={\small\left\{\begin{array}[]{l}\tiny\gamma_{1}(2t),~{}0\leq t<\frac{1}{2}\\ \tiny\gamma_{2}(2t-1),~{}\frac{1}{2}\leq t\leq 1\end{array}\right.}).

Free Group and Free Product of Groups: A free group over a set of letters/symbols is the group whose elements consists of all words constructed out of the letters and their formal inverses, with identity element being the empty word, and the group operation being word concatenation (with any letter juxtaposed with its inverse reducing to the identity) (Scott and Scott, 1964). Given two groups, G𝐺G and H𝐻H, the free product of the groups is the group of words that can be constructed with all the elements of the groups as the letters. The free product is thus written as G∗H={g1​h1​g2​h2​⋯|gi∈G,hi∈H}𝐺𝐻conditional-setsubscript𝑔1subscriptℎ1subscript𝑔2subscriptℎ2⋯formulae-sequencesubscript𝑔𝑖𝐺subscriptℎ𝑖𝐻G*H=\{g_{1}h_{1}g_{2}h_{2}\cdots|g_{i}\in G,h_{i}\in H\}.

2.2 Motivation: Homotopy Invariant in (ℝ2−𝒪)superscriptℝ2𝒪(\mathbb{R}^{2}-\mathcal{O})

We are interested in constructing computable homotopy invariants for trajectories in a configuration space that are amenable to graph search-based path planning. To that end there is a very simple construction for configuration spaces of the form ℝ2−𝒪superscriptℝ2𝒪\mathbb{R}^{2}-\mathcal{O} (Euclidean plane punctured by obstacles) (Grigoriev and Slissenko, 1998; Hershberger and Snoeyink, 1991; Tovar et al., 2008; Bhattacharya et al., 2015; Kim et al., 2014): We start by placing representative points, ζisubscript𝜁𝑖\zeta_{i}, inside the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} connected component of the obstacles, Oi⊂𝒪subscript𝑂𝑖𝒪O_{i}\subset\mathcal{O}. We then construct non-intersecting rays, r1,r2,⋯,rmsubscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2⋯subscript𝑟𝑚r_{1},r_{2},\cdots,r_{m}, emanating from the representative points (this is always possible, for example, by choosing the rays to be parallel to each other). Now, given a curve γ𝛾\gamma in ℝ2−𝒪superscriptℝ2𝒪\mathbb{R}^{2}-\mathcal{O}, we construct a word by tracing the curve, and every time we cross a ray risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i} from its right to left, we insert the letter “risubscript𝑟𝑖r_{i}” into the word, and every time we cross it from left to right, we insert a letter “ri−1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖1r_{i}^{-1}” into the word, with consecutive rjsubscript𝑟𝑗r_{j} and rj−1superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑗1r_{j}^{-1} canceling each other. The word thus constructed is written as h​(γ)ℎ𝛾h(\gamma). For example, in Figure 1(a), h​(γ)=“​r1−1​r4​r2−1​r4−1​r4​r4−1​r6−1​”=“​r1−1​r4​r2−1​r4−1​r6−1​”ℎ𝛾“superscriptsubscript𝑟11subscript𝑟4superscriptsubscript𝑟21superscriptsubscript𝑟41subscript𝑟4superscriptsubscript𝑟41superscriptsubscript𝑟61”“superscriptsubscript𝑟11subscript𝑟4superscriptsubscript𝑟21superscriptsubscript𝑟41superscriptsubscript𝑟61”h(\gamma)=\text{``}r_{1}^{-1}r_{4}~{}r_{2}^{-1}r_{4}^{-1}r_{4}~{}r_{4}^{-1}r_{6}^{-1}\text{''}=\text{``}r_{1}^{-1}r_{4}~{}r_{2}^{-1}r_{4}^{-1}r_{6}^{-1}\text{''}. This word, called the reduced word for the trajectory γ𝛾\gamma, is a complete homotopy invariant for trajectories connecting the same set of points. That is, γ1,γ2:[0,1]→(ℝ2−𝒪):subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2→01superscriptℝ2𝒪\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}:[0,1]\rightarrow(\mathbb{R}^{2}-\mathcal{O}), with γi​(0)=qs,γi​(1)=qeformulae-sequencesubscript𝛾𝑖0subscript𝑞𝑠subscript𝛾𝑖1subscript𝑞𝑒\gamma_{i}(0)=q_{s},\gamma_{i}(1)=q_{e} are homotopic if and only if h​(γ1)=h​(γ2)ℎsubscript𝛾1ℎsubscript𝛾2h(\gamma_{1})=h(\gamma_{2}).

2.3 Words as Homotopy Invariants in Spaces with Free Fundamental Groups

In a more general setting the aforesaid construction can be generalized as follows:

Construction 1

Given a D𝐷D-dimensional manifold (possibly with boundary), X𝑋X, suppose U1,U2,⋯​Unsubscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2⋯subscript𝑈𝑛U_{1},U_{2},\cdots U_{n} are (D−1)𝐷1(D-1)-dimensional orientable sub-manifolds (not necessarily smooth and possibly with boundaries) such that ∂Ui⊆∂Xsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑋\partial U_{i}\subseteq\partial X. Then, for any curve, γ𝛾\gamma (connecting fixed start and end points, xs,xe∈Xsubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑥𝑒𝑋x_{s},x_{e}\in X), which is in general position (transverse) w.r.t. the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s, one can construct a word by tracing the curve and inserting into the word a letter, uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} or ui−1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}^{-1}, whenever the curve intersects Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} with a positive or negative orientation respectively.

The proposition below is a direct consequence of a simple version of the Van Kampen’s Theorem (of which several different generalizations are available in the literature).

Proposition 1

Words constructed as described in Construction 1 are complete homotopy invariants for curves in X𝑋X joining the given start and end points if the following conditions hold:

  1. 1.

    Ui∩Uj=∅,∀i≠jformulae-sequencesubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗for-all𝑖𝑗U_{i}\cap U_{j}=\emptyset,~{}\forall i\neq j.

  2. 2.

    X−⋃i=1nUi𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖X-\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}U_{i} is path connected and simply-connected, and,

  3. 3.

    π1​(X−⋃i=1,i≠jnUi)≃ℤ,∀j=1,2,⋯,nformulae-sequencesimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜋1𝑋superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖ℤfor-all𝑗12⋯𝑛\pi_{1}(X-\bigcup_{i=1,i\neq j}^{n}U_{i})\simeq\mathbb{Z},~{}\forall j=1,2,\cdots,n,

Proof.  Consider the spaces X0=X−⋃i=1nUisubscript𝑋0𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖X_{0}=X-\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}U_{i} and Xj=X−⋃i=1,i≠jnUi,j=1,2,⋯,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑗𝑋superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖𝑗12⋯𝑛X_{j}=X-\bigcup_{i=1,i\neq j}^{n}U_{i},~{}j=1,2,\cdots,n. Due to the aforesaid properties of the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s the set 𝒞X={X0,X1,⋯,Xn}subscript𝒞𝑋subscript𝑋0subscript𝑋1⋯subscript𝑋𝑛\mathcal{C}_{X}=\{X_{0},X_{1},\cdots,X_{n}\} constitutes an open cover of X𝑋X, is closed under intersection, the pairwise intersections Xi∩Xj=X0,i≠jformulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑋0𝑖𝑗X_{i}\cap X_{j}=X_{0},i\neq j are simply-connected (and hence path connected), and so are Xi∩Xj∩Xk=X0,i≠j≠kformulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖subscript𝑋𝑗subscript𝑋𝑘subscript𝑋0𝑖𝑗𝑘X_{i}\cap X_{j}\cap X_{k}=X_{0},i\neq j\neq k.

The proof, when γ𝛾\gamma is a closed loop (i.e. xs=xesubscript𝑥𝑠subscript𝑥𝑒x_{s}=x_{e}), then follows directly from the Seifert-van Kampen theorem (Hatcher, 2001; Crowell, 1959) by observing that π1(X)≃π1(X0)∗π1(X1)∗π1(X2)∗⋯∗π1(Xn)≃∗i=1nℤ\pi_{1}(X)\simeq\pi_{1}(X_{0})*\pi_{1}(X_{1})*\pi_{1}(X_{2})*\cdots*\pi_{1}(X_{n})\simeq{*}_{i=1}^{n}\mathbb{Z}, the free product of n𝑛n copies of ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}, each ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} generated due to the restriction of the curve to Xi,i=1,2,⋯,nformulae-sequencesubscript𝑋𝑖𝑖12⋯𝑛X_{i},~{}i=1,2,\cdots,n.

When γ1subscript𝛾1\gamma_{1} and γ2subscript𝛾2\gamma_{2} are curves (not necessarily closed) joining points xssubscript𝑥𝑠x_{s} and xesubscript𝑥𝑒x_{e}, they are in the same homotopy class iff γ1∪−γ2\gamma_{1}\cup-\gamma_{2} is null-homotopic — that is, h​(γ1)∘h​(−γ2)=“​”⇔h​(γ1)=h​(γ2)⇔ℎsubscript𝛾1ℎsubscript𝛾2“”ℎsubscript𝛾1ℎsubscript𝛾2h(\gamma_{1})\circ h(-\gamma_{2})=\text{``}~{}\text{''}\Leftrightarrow h(\gamma_{1})=h(\gamma_{2}) (where by “∘\circ” we mean word concatenation).
qed. □□\square

The Construction 1 gives a presentation (Epstein, 1992) of the fundamental group of X𝑋X (which, in this case, is a free group due to the Van Kampen’s theorem) as the group generated by the set of letters 𝐔={u1,u2,⋯,uq}𝐔subscript𝑢1subscript𝑢2⋯subscript𝑢𝑞\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}=\{u_{1},u_{2},\cdots,u_{q}\}, and is written as G=π1(X)=<u1,u2,⋯,uq>=<𝐔>G=\pi_{1}(X)=<\!u_{1},u_{2},\cdots,u_{q}\!>=<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}\!>. In our earlier construction with the rays, X=ℝ2−𝒪𝑋superscriptℝ2𝒪X=\mathbb{R}^{2}-\mathcal{O} was the configuration space, and Ui=X∩risubscript𝑈𝑖𝑋subscript𝑟𝑖U_{i}=X\cap r_{i} were the support of the rays in the configuration space. It is easy to check that the conditions in the above proposition are satisfied with these choices. However such choices of rays is not the only possible construction of the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s satisfying the conditions of Proposition 1. Figure 1(b) shows a different choice of the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s that satisfy all the conditions.

2.4 Simple Extension to (ℝ3−𝒪)superscriptℝ3𝒪(\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O}) with Unlinked Unknotted Obstacles

The construction described in Section 2.2 can be easily extended to the 333-dimensional Euclidean space punctured by a finite number of un-knotted and un-linked toroidal (possibly of multi-genus) obstacles. Instead of “rays”, in this case the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s are 222-dimensional sub-manifolds that satisfy the conditions in Proposition 1, with a letter, uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} (or ui−1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}^{-1}), being inserted in h​(γ)ℎ𝛾h(\gamma) every time the curve, γ𝛾\gamma, crosses/intersects a Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}. This is illustrated in Figures 2(a) and 2(b).

However, a little investigation makes it obvious that such 222-dimensional sub-manifolds cannot always be constructed when the obstacle are knotted or linked (Figure 2(c)). One can indeed construct surfaces (e.g. Seifert surfaces) satisfying some of the properties, but not all.

2.5 Application to Graph Search-based Path Planning

Using the homotopy invariants described in the previous sub-section, we describe a graph construction for use in search-based path planning for computing optimal (in the graph) trajectories in different homotopy classes. Suppose G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E) is a discrete graph representation of a configuration space, X𝑋X. That is, V𝑉V, is a set of points (vertices) sampled from X𝑋X, and for any two neighboring points x1,x2∈Vsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝑉x_{1},x_{2}\in V (where neighbors are typically determined by a distance threshold), there exists an edge (x1,x2)∈Esubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝐸(x_{1},x_{2})\in E. 222We assume that the discretization is such that corresponding to every homotopy class in the configuration space there exists at least one path in the graph that successfully captures/represents that homotopy class. This is true if the sampling of the vertices is sufficiently dense in X𝑋X, and the edge connecting neighboring vertices is the shortest path (with respect to the metric of the underlying space) connecting those points in X𝑋X. We assume xs∈Vsubscript𝑥𝑠𝑉x_{s}\in V.

We first fix the set of sub-manifolds {U1,U2,⋯,Un}subscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2⋯subscript𝑈𝑛\{U_{1},U_{2},\cdots,U_{n}\} as described earlier. Now, given a discrete graph representation of the configuration space, G=(V,E)𝐺𝑉𝐸G=(V,E), we construct an hℎh-augmented graph, Gh=(Vh,Eh)subscript𝐺ℎsubscript𝑉ℎsubscript𝐸ℎG_{h}=(V_{h},E_{h}), which is essentially a lift of G𝐺G into the universal covering space of X𝑋X (Hatcher, 2001). The construction of such augmented graphs has been described in our prior work (Bhattacharya et al., 2015; Kim et al., 2014; Govindarajan et al., 2014), and the explicit construction of Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h} can be described as follows:

  1. i.

    Vertices in Vhsubscript𝑉ℎV_{h} are tuples of the form (x,w)𝑥𝑤(x,w), where x∈V𝑥𝑉x\in V and w𝑤w is a word made out of letters uisubscript𝑢𝑖u_{i} and ui−1superscriptsubscript𝑢𝑖1u_{i}^{-1}.

  2. ii.

    (xs,“​”)∈Vhsubscript𝑥𝑠“”subscript𝑉ℎ(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''})\in V_{h}.

  3. iii.

    For every edge [x1,x2]∈Esubscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2𝐸[x_{1},x_{2}]\in E and every vertex (x1,w)∈Vhsubscript𝑥1𝑤subscript𝑉ℎ(x_{1},w)\in V_{h}, there exists an edge [(x1,w),(x2,w∘h​(x1​x2→))]∈Ehsubscript𝑥1𝑤subscript𝑥2𝑤ℎ→subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2subscript𝐸ℎ[(x_{1},w),(x_{2},w\circ h(\overrightarrow{x_{1}x_{2}}))]\in E_{h}, where x1​x2→→subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2\overrightarrow{x_{1}x_{2}} denotes the directed curve that constitutes the edge [x1,x2]subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2[x_{1},x_{2}].

  4. iv.

    The length/cost of an edge in Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h} is same as its projection in G𝐺G: CGh​([(x1,w1),(x2,w2)])=CG​([x1,x2])subscript𝐶subscript𝐺ℎsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑤1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑤2subscript𝐶𝐺subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2C_{G_{h}}\left([(x_{1},w_{1}),(x_{2},w_{2})]\right)=C_{G}([x_{1},x_{2}]).

The item ‘i.’ is just a qualitative description of the vertices in Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h}. Item ‘ii.’ describes one particular vertex in Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h}, and using that, item ‘iii.’ describes an incremental construction of the entire graph Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h}. The topology of Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h} can be described as a lift of G𝐺G into the universal covering space, X~~𝑋\widetilde{X}, of X𝑋X, and is illustrated in Figure 3 for a uniform cylindrically discretized space with a single disk-shaped obstacle.

Such an incremental construction is well-suited for use in graph search algorithms such as Dijkstra’s or A* (Cormen et al., 2001), in which one initiates an open set using the start vertex (in item ii.), and then gradually expands vertices, generating only the neighbors at every expansion (the recipe for which is given by item ‘iii.’). Executing a search (Dijkstra’s/A*) in Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h} from (xs,“​”)subscript𝑥𝑠“”(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''}) to vertices of the form (xe,∗)subscript𝑥𝑒(x_{e},*) (where ‘∗*’ denotes any word), and projecting it back to G𝐺G, gives us optimal trajectories in G𝐺G that belong to different homotopy classes. Figure 4(a) shows 555 such optimal trajectories in the graph, connecting a given start and goal vertex, where G𝐺G was constructed by an uniform hexagonal discretization of the planar configuration space. One can then employ a simple curve shortening algorithm (Kim et al., 2014) to obtain ones more optimal than the ones restricted to G𝐺G (Figure 4(b)). Similarly, shortest trajectories connecting xssubscript𝑥𝑠x_{s} and xesubscript𝑥𝑒x_{e} can be obtained in 333-dimensional configuration spaces with free fundamental group (e.g., Figure 4(d), showing 444 paths connecting two fixed points in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} with two un-linked toroidal obstacles).

3 Knot and Link Complements

As described earlier, when the obstacle set in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} consists of knots and links, it is in general not possible to find the sub-manifolds Ui⊂(ℝ3−𝒪)subscript𝑈𝑖superscriptℝ3𝒪U_{i}\subset(\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O}) as required by Proposition 1. However, thankfully we have more generalized versions of the Van Kampen theorem at our disposal that lets us extend the proposed methodology to such spaces. We first illustrate the generalization in ℝ3−𝒪superscriptℝ3𝒪\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O} using knot/link diagrams.

3.1 Dehn Presentation of Fundamental Group of Knot/Link Complements

For simplicity we consider knots and links in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3} as obstacles. We assume that the knots/links are described by polygons, all of which together constitute O⊂ℝ3𝑂superscriptℝ3O\subset\mathbb{R}^{3}. The thickened obstacles (the knots/links with the tubular neighborhoods) will be referred to as 𝒪𝒪\mathcal{O}. We consider a knot/link diagram (Lickorish, 1997) of the obstacles: Given a projection map, p:ℝ3→ℝ2:𝑝→superscriptℝ3superscriptℝ2p:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{2}, the knot/link diagram is the projection of the knot/link, p​(O)𝑝𝑂p(O), along with additional information about the z𝑧z-ordering at the self-intersections of p​(O)𝑝𝑂p(O). We assume that in this diagram the self-intersections are all transverse (which can always be achieved through infinitesimal perturbations) and that the diagram divides the plane into simply-connected regions (say q𝑞q counts of them) each bounded by segments of the projected obstacles, and one unbounded exterior region. The boundary (the boundary of the closure) of each of the bounded regions is itself a polygon, Qi⊆p​(O),i=1,2,⋯,qformulae-sequencesubscript𝑄𝑖𝑝𝑂𝑖12⋯𝑞Q_{i}\subseteq p(O),~{}i=1,2,\cdots,q (Figure 5(a)). Clearly p−1​(Qi)∩Osuperscript𝑝1subscript𝑄𝑖𝑂p^{-1}(Q_{i})\cap O (the preimage of Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} in the original obstacle) will be a discontinuous polygon, with discontinuities at the preimages of the self-intersection points on the knot diagram. But these discontinuities can be removed simply by “connecting” the preimages at each self-intersection point, resulting into a spatial polygon, Q~isubscript~𝑄𝑖\widetilde{Q}_{i} with the property that p​(Q~i)=Qi𝑝subscript~𝑄𝑖subscript𝑄𝑖p(\widetilde{Q}_{i})=Q_{i}. A simple triangulation can then be employed to construct a surface, Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, in ℝ3−Osuperscriptℝ3𝑂\mathbb{R}^{3}-O, such that its boundary is Q~isubscript~𝑄𝑖\widetilde{Q}_{i} and p​(Ui)𝑝subscript𝑈𝑖p(U_{i}) is the simply-connected region bounded by Qisubscript𝑄𝑖Q_{i} (this can be achieved by first triangulating the planar region, p​(Ui)𝑝subscript𝑈𝑖p(U_{i}), and then lifting the triangulation to ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}) – see Figure 5(a).

The Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s thus constructed satisfy properties (2) and (3) of Proposition 1, but not property (1), nor do they satisfy the property ∂Ui⊆∂Xsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑋\partial U_{i}\subseteq\partial X. The consequence of this is that near the regions where the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s intersect, there can be closed loops in ℝ3−Osuperscriptℝ3𝑂\mathbb{R}^{3}-O which are null-homotopic, but words constructed simply by tracing the loop and inserting letters corresponding to intersections with the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s, as we did earlier, may not be the empty word (identity element). An example is illustrated in Figure 5(b)). Due to our construction, such intersection of the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s happen only along lines passing through the pre-image of the self-intersections in the knot diagram, for each of which we end up getting a null-homotopic closed loop with non-empty word.

The Dehn presentation (Weinbaum, 1971) uses surfaces as constructed to describe the fundamental group of knot/link complements. We consider the free group, G=<u1,u2,⋯,uq>G=<\!u_{1},u_{2},\cdots,u_{q}\!> =<𝐔>absentexpectation𝐔=<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}\!>. In general, for every self-intersection in the knot/link diagram, there are four adjacent surfaces, Ui1,Ui2,Ui3subscript𝑈subscript𝑖1subscript𝑈subscript𝑖2subscript𝑈subscript𝑖3U_{i_{1}},U_{i_{2}},U_{i_{3}} and Ui4subscript𝑈subscript𝑖4U_{i_{4}} in the order as shown in Figure 6 (when the self-intersection is adjacent to the unbounded region in the knot diagram, there are only three). Correspondingly, there is a closed null-homotopic loop, γisubscript𝛾𝑖\gamma_{i}, that has a word ρi=“​ui1​ui2−1​ui3​ui4−1​”subscript𝜌𝑖“subscript𝑢subscript𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑢subscript𝑖21subscript𝑢subscript𝑖3superscriptsubscript𝑢subscript𝑖41”\rho_{i}=\text{``}u_{i_{1}}\,u_{i_{2}}^{-1}u_{i_{3}}\,u_{i_{4}}^{-1}\text{''}. Thus we have such words ρ1,ρ2,⋯,ρmsubscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2⋯subscript𝜌𝑚\rho_{1},\rho_{2},\cdots,\rho_{m} (assuming there are m𝑚m counts of self-intersections) that represent null-homotopic loops. These words are called relations and we call the set 𝐑={ρ1,ρ2,⋯,ρm}𝐑subscript𝜌1subscript𝜌2⋯subscript𝜌𝑚\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}=\{\rho_{1},\rho_{2},\cdots,\rho_{m}\} the relation set. It can be easily noted that inverses and cyclic permutations of each ρisubscript𝜌𝑖\rho_{i} also corresponds to null-homotopic loops. We thus define the symmetricized relation set, 𝐑¯¯𝐑\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}, as the set containing all the words in 𝐑𝐑\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}, all their inverses, and all cyclic permutation of each of those.

Let the normal subgroup of G𝐺G generated by 𝐑¯¯𝐑\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} be N={“​α1​ρi1​α1−1​α2​ρi2​α2−1​⋯​ακ−1​ακ​ρiκ​⋯​”|αk∈G,ρik∈𝐑¯}=<𝐑¯G>𝑁conditional-set“subscript𝛼1subscript𝜌subscript𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝛼11subscript𝛼2subscript𝜌subscript𝑖2superscriptsubscript𝛼21⋯superscriptsubscript𝛼𝜅1subscript𝛼𝜅subscript𝜌subscript𝑖𝜅⋯”formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑘𝐺subscript𝜌subscript𝑖𝑘¯𝐑expectationsuperscript¯𝐑𝐺N=\{\text{``}\alpha_{1}\rho_{i_{1}}\alpha_{1}^{-1}~{}\alpha_{2}\rho_{i_{2}}\alpha_{2}^{-1}\cdots\newline \alpha_{\kappa}^{-1}~{}\alpha_{\kappa}\rho_{i_{\kappa}}\cdots\text{''}~{}|~{}\alpha_{k}\!\in\!G,~{}\rho_{i_{k}}\!\in\!\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}\}=<\!\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}^{G}\!> (normal closure of 𝐑¯¯𝐑\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} in G𝐺G). It is easy to observe that a closed loop, γ𝛾\gamma, in X=ℝ3−𝒪𝑋superscriptℝ3𝒪X=\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O}, has a word that is an element of N𝑁N iff it is null-homotopic. Due to a more general version of the Van Kampen’s theorem (Hatcher, 2001), the fundamental group of X𝑋X is the quotient group, π1​(X)=G/N=<𝐔|𝐑>subscript𝜋1𝑋𝐺𝑁inner-product𝐔𝐑\pi_{1}(X)=G/N=<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!> — the group in which, under the quotient map, elements of N𝑁N are mapped to the identity element. This is summarized and generalized in the following proposition.

Proposition 2

Given a D𝐷D-dimensional manifold (possibly with boundary), X𝑋X, suppose U1,U2,⋯​Unsubscript𝑈1subscript𝑈2⋯subscript𝑈𝑛U_{1},U_{2},\cdots U_{n} are (D−1)𝐷1(D-1)-dimensional orientable sub-manifolds (not necessarily smooth and possibly with boundaries) such that ∂Ui⊆∂X∪⋃j≠iUjsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑋subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗\partial U_{i}\subseteq\partial X\cup\bigcup_{j\neq i}U_{j} and

  1. 1.

    a) The intersections of Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i} and Ujsubscript𝑈𝑗U_{j}, if non-empty, are transverse (hence (D−2)𝐷2(D-2)-dimensional),

  2.   

    b) ⋂i=1nUi=∅superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖\bigcap_{i=1}^{n}U_{i}=\emptyset,

  3. 2.

    X−⋃i=1nUi𝑋superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖X-\bigcup_{i=1}^{n}U_{i} is path connected and simply-connected, and,

  4. 3.

    π1​(X−⋃i=1,i≠jnUi)≃ℤ,∀j=1,2,⋯,nformulae-sequencesimilar-to-or-equalssubscript𝜋1𝑋superscriptsubscriptformulae-sequence𝑖1𝑖𝑗𝑛subscript𝑈𝑖ℤfor-all𝑗12⋯𝑛\pi_{1}(X-\bigcup_{i=1,i\neq j}^{n}U_{i})\simeq\mathbb{Z},~{}\forall j=1,2,\cdots,n,

For a loop in X𝑋X, as before, one can construct a word as described in Construction 1. Let the set of all the letters constituting such words be 𝐔𝐔\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}.

For every (D−2)𝐷2(D-2)-dimensional intersection of the Ui∩Uj,i≠jsubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗𝑖𝑗U_{i}\cap U_{j},~{}i\neq j, one can construct a loop in the tubular neighborhood of Ui∩Ujsubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗U_{i}\cap U_{j} in X𝑋X that links with Ui∩Ujsubscript𝑈𝑖subscript𝑈𝑗U_{i}\cap U_{j}. Let the set of words corresponding to such loops be 𝐑𝐑\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}.

Then the fundamental group of X𝑋X is isomorphic to <𝐔|𝐑>inner-product𝐔𝐑<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!>.

3.2 The Word Problem and Dehn Algorithm

Due to the discussion above, two trajectories, γ1,γ2subscript𝛾1subscript𝛾2\gamma_{1},\gamma_{2}, connecting xssubscript𝑥𝑠x_{s} and xesubscript𝑥𝑒x_{e} in the knot/link complement, X𝑋X, belong to the same homotopy class iff the word h(γ1∪−γ2)=h(γ1)∘h(γ2)−1h(\gamma_{1}\cup-\gamma_{2})=h(\gamma_{1})\circ h(\gamma_{2})^{-1} belongs to N=<𝐑¯G>𝑁expectationsuperscript¯𝐑𝐺N=<\!\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}^{G}\!>. This problem in group theory is known as the word problem (Epstein, 1992), and there are various algorithms, each suitable for specific types of groups, for solving the word problem. We, in particular, will focus on a very simple algorithm due to Max Dehn (Lyndon and Schupp, 2001; Greendlinger and Greendlinger, 1986), which is applicable to a wide class of groups and their presentations.

Dehn’s metric algorithm: Given a presentation of a group, π1=<𝐔|𝐑>subscript𝜋1inner-product𝐔𝐑\pi_{1}=<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!>, we construct the symmetricized relation set 𝐑¯¯𝐑\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} as described earlier. Given a cyclically reduced word, w𝑤w, made up of letters (and their inverses) from 𝐔𝐔\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}, one checks for every element ρ∈𝐑¯𝜌¯𝐑\rho\in\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}} if w𝑤w and ρ𝜌\rho share a common sub-words that is of length greater than |ρ|/2𝜌2|\rho|/2 (|ρ|𝜌|\rho| being the length of ρ𝜌\rho). If they do (say, ρ=α​β​γ𝜌𝛼𝛽𝛾\rho=\alpha\beta\gamma, with β𝛽\beta being a sub-word appearing in w𝑤w, and |β|>|ρ|/2𝛽𝜌2|\beta|>|\rho|/2), we replace the sub-word with the shorter equivalent that one obtains by setting ρ𝜌\rho to the identity element (i.e., replace β𝛽\beta by α−1​γ−1superscript𝛼1superscript𝛾1\alpha^{-1}\gamma^{-1} in w𝑤w). This process is repeated, and the algorithm terminates when no more such sub-words are found. The final word at which the algorithm terminates indicates if the initial word, w𝑤w, is in N𝑁N (whether it maps to the identity element in π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1}).

This algorithm can be used in conjunction with search in Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h} as before for finding optimal trajectories in different homotopy classes, with two vertices (x,w1),(x,w2)∈Vh𝑥subscript𝑤1𝑥subscript𝑤2subscript𝑉ℎ(x,w_{1}),(x,w_{2})\in V_{h} being the same iff h​(w1)∘h​(−w2)ℎsubscript𝑤1ℎsubscript𝑤2h(w_{1})\circ h(-w_{2}) reduces to the empty word upon applying the Dehn’s metric algorithm.

3.3 Guarantees of Dehn Algorithm

It’s well known (Greendlinger and Greendlinger, 1986) that if Dehn algorithm terminates at the empty word, then w∈N𝑤𝑁w\in N. However, the converse is not necessarily true. One can derive several sufficient (and often highly restrictive) conditions on the presentation <𝐔|𝐑>inner-product𝐔𝐑<\!\mathsf{\mathbf{U}}~{}|~{}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}\!> under which the converse holds (Lyndon and Schupp, 2001). If, for a given presentation of a group the converse holds, we say that Dehn algorithm is complete for that presentation (or that the presentation is complete with respect to the Dehn algorithm, or that the word problem is solvable using the specific presentation and Dehn algorithm).

Due to the result of (Weinbaum, 1971), the Dehn presentation of the fundamental groups of the complement of a tame, alternating, prime knot is complete with respect to the Dehn algorithm. It is also known (Epstein, 1992) that automatic groups (including hyperbolic groups) have presentations that are complete with respect to Dehn algorithm.

4 Cylindrically-deleted Configuration Spaces

The previous results are limited to 3-dimensional spaces: one suspects that higher dimensions are more difficult. However, there are some classes of spaces for which optimal path-planning with homotopy constraints is still computable via a Dehn algorithm, independent of dimension. The following class of examples is inspired by robot coordination problems, in which individual agents with predetermined motion paths have to coordinate their motions so as to avoid collision.

Consider a collection of n𝑛n graphs (Γi)1nsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptΓ𝑖1𝑛(\Gamma_{i})_{1}^{n}, each embedded in a common workspace (usually ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2} or ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}) with intersections permitted. In the simplest case, each ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i} will be homeomorphic to a closed interval, but more general graphs are permitted, such as roadmap approximations to a configuration space. On each ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i}, a robot Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} with some particular fixed size/shape is free to move. Such motion may be Euclidean (by translation/rotation); more general motions are possible, so long as the region occupied by the robot Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} in the workspace is purely a function of location on ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i}. A point in the product space ∏iΓisubscriptproduct𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} determines the locations of the n𝑛n robots in the common workspace. Certain configurations are illegal, due to collisions. For example, if the robots are point-like, and each Γi=ΓsubscriptΓ𝑖Γ\Gamma_{i}=\Gamma is identical, then the configuration space of n𝑛n points on ΓΓ\Gamma is the cross product ∏iΓisubscriptproduct𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} minus the pairwise diagonal ΔΔ\Delta. If the robots are given finite extent, then this system has a configuration space obtained by the graph product ∏iΓisubscriptproduct𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} minus an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-neighborhood of the pairwise diagonal. However, more general types of collisions can be defined, say, if the robots are irregularly shaped and the graphs ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i} are all different. In this most general case, the natural analogue of a configuration space is the coordination spaces of (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006).

The coordination space of this system is defined to be the space of all configurations in ∏iΓisubscriptproduct𝑖subscriptΓ𝑖\prod_{i}\Gamma_{i} for which there are no collisions – the geometric robots Risubscript𝑅𝑖R_{i} have no overlaps in the workspace. Under the assumption that collisions between robots are pairwise-defined, the coordination space is cylindrically deleted and of the form

X=(∏i=1nΓi)−𝒪​where​𝒪=⋃i<j{(xk)1N∈∏k=1NΓk:(xi,xj)∈Δi,j},𝑋superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑖1𝑛subscriptΓ𝑖𝒪where𝒪subscript𝑖𝑗conditional-setsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑥𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑁subscriptΓ𝑘subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscriptΔ𝑖𝑗X=\left(\prod_{i=1}^{n}\Gamma_{i}\right)-{\mathcal{O}}\quad{\rm where}\quad{\mathcal{O}}=\bigcup_{i<j}\left\{(x_{k})_{1}^{N}\in\prod_{k=1}^{N}\Gamma_{k}\,:\,(x_{i},x_{j})\in\Delta_{i,j}\right\},

for some (open, “collision”) sets Δi,j⊂Γi×ΓjsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑗subscriptΓ𝑖subscriptΓ𝑗\Delta_{i,j}\subset\Gamma_{i}\times\Gamma_{j} where 1≤i<j≤N1𝑖𝑗𝑁1\leq i<j\leq N. In what follows, we assume that the Δi,jsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑗\Delta_{i,j} are sufficiently tame (e.g., semialgebraic) so as to avoid issues of non-finitely-generated π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1}. Given (internal, path-) metrics on each ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i}, the coordination space X𝑋X inherits a locally-Euclidean metric on products of edges in the graphs. Such X𝑋X are complete path-spaces and thus the problem of geodesics is well-posed. Their fundamental groups can be (highly) nontrivial, depending on the obstacle set 𝒪𝒪{\mathcal{O}}. However, finding optimal paths subject to homotopy classes is still computable. To that end one can construct the subspaces Ui⊂Xsubscript𝑈𝑖𝑋U_{i}\subset X of co-dimension 111, and the relation set 𝐑𝐑\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}, and use them to design complete homotopy invariants as before. We do not discuss the explicit construction of the Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}’s for cylindrically-deleted coordination spaces in this paper, but provide the following theorem on solvability of the word problem in such spaces.

Theorem 1

Any compact cylindrically-deleted coordination space X𝑋X admits a Dehn algorithm for π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1}.

Proof.  Any such X𝑋X is realized as a Hausdorff limit of cubcial complexes which were shown in (Ghrist and LaValle, 2006, Thm 4.4) to be nonpositively-curved and to stabilize in π1subscript𝜋1\pi_{1} by tameness. All nonpositively-curved piecewise-Euclidean cube complexes have fundamental groups which are, by a famous result of Niblo-Reeves (Niblo and Reeves, 1998), biautomatic. Biautomatic groups all admit a Dehn algorithm (specifically, there is a quadratic isoperimetric inequality) (Epstein, 1992).
qed. □□\square

It is worth noting that ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}-shortest paths are perhaps not the most natural optimization for coordination spaces. It would be interesting to consider other (ℓ1subscriptℓ1\ell_{1}, ℓ∞subscriptℓ\ell_{\infty}) pointwise norms.

In the next section we consider point robots navigating on a plane. The configuration space of each robot is the Euclidean plane. For such a configuration space for the individual robots, the result of Theorem 1 may not hold, since the fundamental group of the coordination space may not be biautomatic. Nevertheless, we can construct a presentation of the fundamental group, which we do, and still apply Dehn metric algorithm to it, although the Dehn algorithm may not be complete for the proposed presentation.

4.1 Presentation of the Fundamental Group of a Cylindrically Deleted Coordination Space for Point Robots Navigating on a Plane

We consider point robots navigating on a plane. Thus, in this case ΓisubscriptΓ𝑖\Gamma_{i}, the configuration space of the it​hsuperscript𝑖𝑡ℎi^{th} robot, is the Euclidean plane coordinatized by (xi,yi)subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖(x_{i},y_{i}). A collision set Δi,j={(xi,yi,xj,yj)|xi=xj,yi=yj}⊂Γi×Γj≃ℝ4,1≤i<j≤Nformulae-sequencesubscriptΔ𝑖𝑗conditional-setsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑗formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗subscriptΓ𝑖subscriptΓ𝑗similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptℝ41𝑖𝑗𝑁\Delta_{i,j}=\{(x_{i},y_{i},x_{j},y_{j})~{}|~{}x_{i}\!=\!x_{j},y_{i}\!=\!y_{j}\}\subset\Gamma_{i}\times\Gamma_{j}\simeq\mathbb{R}^{4},~{}1\!\leq\!i\!<\!j\!\leq\!N, is a 222-dimensional hyperplane embedded in the joint configuration space of the robots i𝑖i and j𝑗j.

The joint configuration space of N𝑁N robots (with the collision sets included) is Γ¯=∏k=1NΓk≃ℝ2​N¯Γsuperscriptsubscriptproduct𝑘1𝑁subscriptΓ𝑘similar-to-or-equalssuperscriptℝ2𝑁\overline{\Gamma}=\prod_{k=1}^{N}\Gamma_{k}\simeq\mathbb{R}^{2N}. The “cylindrical” obstacles in this configuration space created due to Δi,jsubscriptΔ𝑖𝑗\Delta_{i,j} are thus

𝒪i,j=Δi,j×(∏k≠i,jΓk)={(x1,y1,x2,y2,⋯,xN,yN)|xi=xj,yi=yj}⊂Γ¯,subscript𝒪𝑖𝑗subscriptΔ𝑖𝑗subscriptproduct𝑘𝑖𝑗subscriptΓ𝑘conditional-setsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2⋯subscript𝑥𝑁subscript𝑦𝑁formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗¯Γ\mathcal{O}_{i,j}=\Delta_{i,j}\times\left(\prod_{k\neq i,j}\Gamma_{k}\right)=\{(x_{1},y_{1},x_{2},y_{2},\cdots,x_{N},y_{N})~{}|~{}x_{i}\!=\!x_{j},y_{i}\!=\!y_{j}\}\subset\overline{\Gamma},

which are co-dimension 222 subspaces (hyperplanes) embedded in the 2​N2𝑁2N dimensional joint configuration space. Thus the coordination space is X=Γ¯−⋃1≤i<j≤N𝒪i,j𝑋¯Γsubscript1𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝒪𝑖𝑗X=\overline{\Gamma}-\bigcup_{1\leq i<j\leq N}\mathcal{O}_{i,j}.

4.1.1 Design of co-dimension 111 manifolds, U∗subscript𝑈U_{*}:

As before, we are interested in constructing a set of (2​N−1)2𝑁1(2N-1)-dimensional sub-manifolds, {Uα}subscript𝑈𝛼\{U_{\alpha}\}, in X𝑋X such that removing all but one of these sub-manifolds will give us a space with fundamental group isomorphic to ℤℤ\mathbb{Z}. This would let us apply the generalized Van Kampen theorem as before by allowing us to construct words based on transverse intersection of paths with the surfaces, U∗subscript𝑈U_{*} (which would be of co-dimension 111 in X𝑋X). We outline a general construction, and then show how that can be specialized for N=3𝑁3N=3.

Consider a single (2​N−2)2𝑁2(2N-2)-dimensional obstacle 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j}, which is a hyperplane of co-dimension 222 in Γ¯¯Γ\overline{\Gamma}. Thus the homotopy group of Yi,j=Γ¯−𝒪i,jsubscript𝑌𝑖𝑗¯Γsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗Y_{i,j}=\overline{\Gamma}-\mathcal{O}_{i,j} is isomorphic to ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} and is generated by a 111-dimensional loop that links with 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j} in this space. Our first construction corresponding to the obstacle 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j} is thus the following half-space:

𝒰i,j={(x1,y1,x2,y2,⋯,xN,yN)|xi=xj,yi<yj}subscript𝒰𝑖𝑗conditional-setsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2⋯subscript𝑥𝑁subscript𝑦𝑁formulae-sequencesubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑥𝑗subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗\mathcal{U}_{i,j}=\{(x_{1},y_{1},x_{2},y_{2},\cdots,x_{N},y_{N})~{}|~{}x_{i}\!=\!x_{j},y_{i}\!<\!y_{j}\}

Lemma 1

X−⋃1≤i<j≤N𝒰i,j=Γ¯−⋃1≤i<j≤N𝒪i,j−⋃1≤i<j≤N𝒰i,j𝑋subscript1𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝒰𝑖𝑗¯Γsubscript1𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝒪𝑖𝑗subscript1𝑖𝑗𝑁subscript𝒰𝑖𝑗X-\bigcup_{1\leq i<j\leq N}\mathcal{U}_{i,j}~{}=~{}\overline{\Gamma}-\bigcup_{1\leq i<j\leq N}\mathcal{O}_{i,j}-\bigcup_{1\leq i<j\leq N}\mathcal{U}_{i,j}  is path connected.

Lemma 2

Any loop in Γ¯¯Γ\overline{\Gamma} linked only with 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j} can be homotoped into any other loop linked only with 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j}, through a sequence of loops linked to 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j},

  1. i.

    without intersecting 𝒪i′,j′subscript𝒪superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′\mathcal{O}_{i^{\prime},j^{\prime}}.

  2. ii.

    not without intersecting 𝒰i′,j′subscript𝒰superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′\mathcal{U}_{i^{\prime},j^{\prime}} if either i=i′,j′<jformulae-sequence𝑖superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′𝑗i\!=\!i^{\prime},~{}j^{\prime}\!<\!j or i<i′,j=j′formulae-sequence𝑖superscript𝑖′𝑗superscript𝑗′i\!<\!i^{\prime},~{}j\!=\!j^{\prime}, otherwise without intersecting 𝒰i′,j′subscript𝒰superscript𝑖′superscript𝑗′\mathcal{U}_{i^{\prime},j^{\prime}}.

Sketch of proof.  The proof is based on being able to construct, or an obstruction to constructing, a homotopy satisfying certain properties between small loops (in a tubular neighborhood of 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j}) lying in a plane transverse to 𝒪i,jsubscript𝒪𝑖𝑗\mathcal{O}_{i,j} and linking to it.

Clearly, given the parameters (c∗0,d∗0)subscriptsuperscript𝑐0subscriptsuperscript𝑑0(c^{0}_{*},d^{0}_{*}) and (c∗1,d∗1)subscriptsuperscript𝑐1subscriptsuperscript𝑑1(c^{1}_{*},d^{1}_{*}), if 2​cn0−cm​p02subscriptsuperscript𝑐0𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑐0𝑚𝑝2c^{0}_{n}-c^{0}_{mp} and 2​cn1−cm​p12subscriptsuperscript𝑐1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑐1𝑚𝑝2c^{1}_{n}-c^{1}_{mp} are of opposite sign, it is not possible to find the path (c∗t,d∗t)subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑡(c^{t}_{*},d^{t}_{*}) such that neither of these rays of intersection do not pass through the origin in 𝒫m,p​(c∗t,d∗t)subscript𝒫𝑚𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝑐𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑑𝑡\mathcal{P}_{m,p}(c^{t}_{*},d^{t}_{*}).
qed. □□\square

The consequence of the above Lemma is that the obstruction to fundamental group of Xm,p=X−∪(i′,j′)≠(m,p),1≤i′<j′≤N𝒰i′,j′X_{m,p}=X-\cup_{(i^{\prime},j^{\prime})\neq(m,p),1\leq i^{\prime}<j^{\prime}\leq N}\mathcal{U}_{i^{\prime},j^{\prime}} being ℤℤ\mathbb{Z} are the intersections of 𝒰m,psubscript𝒰𝑚𝑝\mathcal{U}_{m,p} with 𝒰m,nsubscript𝒰𝑚𝑛\mathcal{U}_{m,n} and 𝒰n,psubscript𝒰𝑛𝑝\mathcal{U}_{n,p}, for every n𝑛n such that m<n<p𝑚𝑛𝑝m<n<p. This leads us to split 𝒰m,psubscript𝒰𝑚𝑝\mathcal{U}_{m,p} by the the hyperplane at which it is intersected by 𝒰m,nsubscript𝒰𝑚𝑛\mathcal{U}_{m,n} or 𝒰n,psubscript𝒰𝑛𝑝\mathcal{U}_{n,p}, for every m<n<p𝑚𝑛𝑝m<n<p. The relation set consists of the following words:

𝐑={u1,2u1,3⁣/−u2,3u1,2−1u1,3⁣/+−1u2,3−1,u1,2​u1,3⁣/−​u1,2−1​u1,3⁣/+−1,u1,3⁣/−u2,3u1,3⁣/+−1u2,3−1}\begin{array}[]{rl}\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}=&\big{\{}~{}~{}u_{1,2}~{}~{}u_{1,3/-}~{}~{}u_{2,3}~{}~{}u_{1,2}^{-1}~{}~{}u_{1,3/+}^{-1}~{}~{}u_{2,3}^{-1},\\ &\qquad u_{1,2}~{}~{}u_{1,3/-}~{}~{}u_{1,2}^{-1}~{}~{}u_{1,3/+}^{-1},\\ &\qquad\quad u_{1,3/-}~{}~{}u_{2,3}~{}~{}u_{1,3/+}^{-1}~{}~{}u_{2,3}^{-1}~{}~{}\big{\}}\end{array}

For simplicity, define a=u1,2𝑎subscript𝑢12a=u_{1,2},  b=u1,3⁣/+𝑏subscript𝑢13absentb=u_{1,3/+},  c=u1,3⁣/−𝑐subscript𝑢13absentc=u_{1,3/-},  d=u2,3𝑑subscript𝑢23d=u_{2,3}. Rewriting the relation set, 𝐑={a​c​d​a−1​b​d−1,a​c​a−1​b,c​d​b​d−1}𝐑𝑎𝑐𝑑superscript𝑎1𝑏superscript𝑑1𝑎𝑐superscript𝑎1𝑏𝑐𝑑𝑏superscript𝑑1\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}=\{acda^{-1}bd^{-1},aca^{-1}b,cdbd^{-1}\}. This can be easily shown (by isolating b𝑏b by setting the last relation to identity, and substituting it in the other two relations) to be isomorphic to the group <a,c,d|a​c​d​(d​a​c)−1,c​d​a​(d​a​c)−1>inner-product𝑎𝑐𝑑𝑎𝑐𝑑superscript𝑑𝑎𝑐1𝑐𝑑𝑎superscript𝑑𝑎𝑐1<a,c,d~{}|~{}acd(dac)^{-1},cda(dac)^{-1}>. Which in turn (using substitution p=c​d,q=d​a​cformulae-sequence𝑝𝑐𝑑𝑞𝑑𝑎𝑐p=cd,q=dac) can be shown to be isomorphic to the group
<a,p,q|a​p​(p​a)−1,a​q​(q​a)−1>inner-product𝑎𝑝𝑞𝑎𝑝superscript𝑝𝑎1𝑎𝑞superscript𝑞𝑎1<a,p,q~{}|~{}ap(pa)^{-1},aq(qa)^{-1}> (a𝑎a commutes with both p𝑝p and q𝑞q, but p𝑝p and q𝑞q themselves do not commute). This is clearly the group ℤ×(ℤ∗ℤ)ℤℤℤ\mathbb{Z}\times(\mathbb{Z}*\mathbb{Z}). In fact, simply using geometric arguments, it is easy to verify that the homotopy type of the coordination space of 333 robots on a plane is indeed that of 𝕊1×(𝕊1∨𝕊1)superscript𝕊1superscript𝕊1superscript𝕊1\mathbb{S}^{1}\times(\mathbb{S}^{1}\vee\mathbb{S}^{1}) (see (Arslan et al., 2016) for example).

5 Simulation Results

5.1 Knot and Link Complements

Given obstacles 𝒪⊂ℝ3𝒪superscriptℝ3\mathcal{O}\subset\mathbb{R}^{3}, and their “skeletons” (111-dimensional homotopy equivalents), O⊆𝒪𝑂𝒪O\subseteq\mathcal{O} as polygons in ℝ3superscriptℝ3\mathbb{R}^{3}, we first choose a projection map, p:ℝ3→ℝ2:𝑝→superscriptℝ3superscriptℝ2p:\mathbb{R}^{3}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{2}, for the knot/link diagram. With this information, we implemented the automated construction of the surfaces, Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, for the Dehn presentation of the knot/link complement, and the symmetricized relation set, 𝐑¯¯𝐑\overline{\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}}, by computing the self-intersections in p​(O)𝑝𝑂p(O). We then used a uniform cubical discretization of ℝ3−𝒪superscriptℝ3𝒪\mathbb{R}^{3}-\mathcal{O} to construct the graph G𝐺G as a discrete representation of the free space, and in the hℎh-augmented graph, Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h}, we find trajectories from (xs,“​”)subscript𝑥𝑠“”(x_{s},\text{``}~{}\text{''}) to (xg,∗)subscript𝑥𝑔(x_{g},*). We then employ a curve shortening algorithm to shorten the obtained trajectories. All our implementations were done in C++ programming language and visualization were done using OpenGL. The program ran on a laptop running on a Intel i7-4500U processor @ 1.80GHz with 8 GB memory.

Figure 8(a) shows results in the complement of a trefoil knot. The inset figure shows the surfaces, Uisubscript𝑈𝑖U_{i}, used for Dehn presentation. The graph G𝐺G was constructed out of uniform 100×100×100100100100100\!\times\!100\!\times\!100 cubical discretization of the environment. As seen in the figure, using the proposed search-based algorithm we computed 555 shortest paths in different homotopy classes and used curve-shortening algorithms to shorten them to obtain the piece-wise linear paths. The entire computation (computation of the surfaces, the symmetricized relation set 𝐑𝐑\mathsf{\mathbf{R}}, and computation of the 555 shortest trajectories) required about 8.18.18.1 s. Likewise, Figure 8(b) shows results in the complement of a simple Hopf link, with the same discretization of the environment, and total computation time of about 8.28.28.2 s.

Figure 8(c) shows a much more complex obstacle involving a torus knot linked to a genus-222 obstacle, and the entire computation of 202020 trajectories took about 2.62.62.6 s. While in a complex space as this, the completeness of Dehn algorithm is not guaranteed, numerical computation still gives us reasonable results as can be seen in this simulation result.

It is interesting to observe that computing shortest paths in 555 different classes in the environments of Figures 8(a) and 8(b) took significantly longer than the computation of 202020 classes in the environment of Figure 8(c). This is because in Figure 8(c), although much more complex, the obstacles themselves occupy a large part of the environment. This significantly reduces the number of vertices and edges in the discrete graph representing the free configuration space than the trefoil knot and Hopf link complements. Thus the graph search runs much faster in the configuration space of Figure 8(c).

5.2 Coordination Space of 333 Robots Navigating on a Plane

Similar to the method described in Section 2.5, we implemented the graph search based approach for finding optimal paths in the coordination space of 333 robots navigating on a planar region. We constructed a graph using a uniform hyper-cubical discretization of the configuration space, Γ¯=ℝ6¯Γsuperscriptℝ6\overline{\Gamma}=\mathbb{R}^{6}, placing a vertex in each cell, and establishing edges between neighboring cells that correspond to robot motions parallel to the coordinate axes. The optimality criteria in the A* search was chosen to be the sum of the total lengths of the paths (which, because of the chosen discretization, is the length due to the Manhattan metric on the plane) traversed by the robots. The hℎh-augmented graph construction from this graph is similar to what has been described in Section 2.5. However for checking whether or not two hℎh-signatures are the same, we use the Dehn algorithm on the presentation described in Example 4.1.3.

Figure 9 (also, in attached multimedia file) shows paths found in 555 different homotopy classes for the coordination space of 333 robots navigating on a plane. With the plane discretized into 7×7777\times 7 grid, and the degree of each vertex in the corresponding joint configuration space being 124124124 (allowing each robot to move north, south, east or west, or stay in place), the computation of paths in 555 different homotopy classes in the coordination space took about 31.731.731.7 s. A careful observation of the figures will indeed reveal that the paths shown in each of the Figures 9 (a)-(e) correspond to the robots taking distinct homotopy classes in the joint configuration space.

5.3 Some Remarks on Number of Homotopy Classes:

As described earlier, we compute the paths in the different homotopy classes by executing graph search algorithms (Dijkstra’s/A*) on the hℎh-augmented graph, Ghsubscript𝐺ℎG_{h}. As a result we obtain the paths in the different homotopy classes in order of their path lengths/costs. Technically, the number of homotopy classes in any of the configuration spaces described earlier infinite. This is because a path can loop/wind round an obstacle arbitrarily many times, thus creating arbitrarily many different homotopy classes. In the simulations we restrict ourselves to the computation of the first few homotopy classes in each configuration space since those are the classes that are most relevant in robotics applications.

6 Conclusion and Future Work

We presented explicit construction of presentations of the fundamental group of two different classes of spaces: Knot/link complements in Euclidean 333-dimensional spaces, and cylindrically deleted coordination space of multiple robots. We thus used graph search-based optimal path planning method for computing optimal paths in different homotopy classes in such environments. These spaces are highly relevant in many robot motion planning problems, for example unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) navigating inside buildings, and multiple ground robots navigating on a plane. Being able to compute optimal paths in different homotopy classes allow us to efficiently solve motion planning problems for complex systems such as tethered robots and systems involving cables, and design strategies for effectively deploying groups of robots in coverage and exploration tasks.

Moving forward, we will use the developed technique for homotopy path planning in 3-dimensional spaces with obstacles for computing optimal traversable paths for tethered unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs). One of the greatest challenges currently faced by UAVs is the limited battery life, which in turn limits the UAVs’ flight time. Having the UAV tethered to a power supply will help alleviate the problem. But in that case one needs to carefully plan paths that satisfy the cable length constraints and prevents the cable from getting tangled in obstacles. Since a real UAV experiment will involve significant amount of investment in terms of equipments, time and development of low-level controllers, we believe an experiment as that is outside the scope of the current paper and will require significant deviation from the theoretical & algorithmic focus of the current paper. We thus propose such an experiment as a future work. But we believe that the new algorithmic tools proposed in this paper will be helpful in solving this real problem in 3-d.
